hierarchyDesc.label: AiAnlymd
hierarchyDesc.scopeNote: Hierarchy for Avian Influenza data collection

hierarchyDesc.name: AILabAnlymd
hierarchyDesc.label: AILabAnlymd
hierarchyDesc.scopeNote: Hierarchy for reporting Avian Influenza laboratory data according to the SIGMA SSD2 data model

hierarchyDesc.name: OHAnlymd
hierarchyDesc.label: OHAnlymd
hierarchyDesc.scopeNote: Hierarchy for reporting data in the context of the One Health surveillance mandate, i.e., hierarchy which encompasses the analytical methods used in the laboratory for the identification of those pathogens to be reported within the remit of One Health mandate

Screening method for the detection of antibiotics in animal products

Screening method for the detection of antibiotics in animal products
Screening method for the detection of antibiotics in animal products
High performance liquid chromatography with diode array detection
Gas chromatography - Automated thermal desorption
Atomic absorption spectroscopy - Advanced mercury analyzer

Commercially available test used to define antimicrobial resistance by adding a bacterial suspension to microtitred wells containing a range of concentrations of the antimicrobials tested. The lowest concentration value at which the bacterial growth is in
Diffusion describes the spread of particles through random motion from regions of higher concentration to regions of lower concentration, driven by a concentration gradient.
Analytical method measuring principle is known, but could not be classified.
Applies to e.g. smelling, tasting, etc.… - not usual for "chemical occurrence" as contaminants or pesticide residues.
Applies to e.g. reacting with reagents and measuring the results of the reaction like precipitation or change of colour, etc (does not apply to colorimetry, photometry and spectroscopy).

attributeValues.attributeValue: Traditional analytical techniques (wet chemical tests) (not specified)

termDesc.termScopeNote: A reagent (called titrator) of a known concentration (a standard solution) and volume is used to react with a solution of the analyte (called titrand), whose concentration is not known e.g. acidimetry, chelatometry, etc.
Quantifying an analyte by measuring physical properties i.e. refractometry, densitometry, etc. (does not apply to colorimetry, photometry and spectroscopy).

Tests based on a chemical or enzymatic reaction with reagents and trough the observation of the results of the reaction like precipitation or change of colour, etc. Only approximate quantification is possible.

Identifying and quantifying one or more analytes through the respective spectrum of absorption and/or emission. If quantification is the main focus of the method, the term "spectrometry" is widely used.
Identifying and quantifying an analyte by measuring electrochemical properties.

termDesc.termExtendedName: Electrochemical tests based on potentiometry (pH electrodes, ionsensitive electrodes, potentiometry)
termDesc.termScopeNote: Potentiometry passively measures the potential of a solution between two electrodes, affecting the solution very little in the process. The potential is then related to the concentration of one or more analytes.

attributeValues.attributeValue: Electrochemical tests based on potentiometry (pH electrodes, ionsensitive electrodes, potentiometry)

termDesc.termScopeNote: Voltammetry applies a constant and/or varying potential at an electrode's surface and measures the resulting current with a three electrode system. Polarimetry is a subclass of voltammetry. Amperometry is also a subclass of voltammetry.
Chromatographic tests with main focus on isolation of the analyte and providing qualitative or semiquantitative results.

termDesc.termExtendedName: Standard Chromatographic tests (paper- thin layer- and column chromatography)
termDesc.termScopeNote: Applies to e.g. TLC

attributeValues.attributeValue: Standard Chromatographic tests (paper- thin layer- and column chromatography)

Standard detector equipment of GC, identification of the analyte is possible comparing the retention time with a standard, quantification can be done using the detector signal (e.g. GC-FID, GC-ECD, GC-NPD, GC-ELCD, GC-FPD, etc.).

A method for determining the concentration of a substance in a solution by measuring the loss in intensity of a light beam through a solution that contains suspended particulate matter.

termDesc.termScopeNote: Quantification of the analyte mass by gravimetric analysis. It determines the amount of material present by weighing the sample before and/or after some transformation e.g. precipitation, drying and ashing. Outside the chemical analysis domain, this term is used to specify all analyses determining the proportion by weigh of any component that can be separated from a mixed sample (e.g. damaged grains in a cereal sample).

termDesc.termExtendedName: Competition ELISA + a seroneutralisation specific for WNV

termDesc.termScopeNote: Nested PCR is a technique that reduces nonspecific amplification of the DNA template. It is performed by two successive PCRs. The first reaction is performed with primers that cover the target sequence and some additional sequence flanking both ends of the target sequence. After the first reaction, a second reaction is performed on the products of the first PCR with primers that bind to the target sequence and are within the amplified sequence of the first PCR. This reduces the amount of nonspecific binding because in the second reaction, most of the amplicons of the first reaction only contain the target sequence and its surrounding sequences.
